info.title: Framing the News: From Human Perception to Large Language Model Inferences
institutes: Idiap Research Institute and EPFL Switzerland
info.abstract: Identifying the frames of news is important to understand the articles vision, intention, message to be conveyed, and which aspects of the news are emphasized. Framing is a widely studied concept in journalism, and has emerged as a new topic in computing, with the potential to automate processes and facilitate the work of journalism professionals. In this paper, we study this issue with articles related to the Covid19 antivaccine movement. First, to understand the perspectives used to treat this theme, we developed a protocol for human labeling of frames for 1786 headlines of No Vax movement articles of European newspapers from 5 countries. Headlines are key units in the written press, and worth of analysis as many people only read headlines (or use them to guide their decision for further reading.) Second, considering advances in Natural Language Processing (NLP) with large language models, we investigated two approaches for frame inference of news headlines: first with a GPT3.5 finetuning approach, and second with GPT 3.5 promptengineering. Our work contributes to the study and analysis of the performance that these models have to facilitate journalistic tasks like classification of frames, while understanding whether the models are able to replicate human perception in the identification of these frames.

content: introduction in recent there has been a proliferation in the use of concepts such as data computational and computer assisted reporting which all share the vision of bridging journalism and the progress made in nlp has been gradually integrated into the journalistic field more machine learning models based on transformers have been integrated in the media sector in different tasks such as the creation of headlines with generative languages models summarization of news articles false news detection and topic modeling and sentiment analysis the development of large language models such as bloom or chatgpt show a clear trend towards humanmachine interaction becoming easier and more opening up a wide range of research at the same the use of these models is also associated with a lack of transparency regarding how these models but efforts are being made to bring some transparency to these and to analyze use cases where they can be useful and where they cannot based on the premises that these models open up a wide range of research directions and that at the same time needless to they are not the solution to all we are interested in identifying use cases and tasks where they can be potentially while acknowledging and systematically documenting their limitations more the aim of this work is to analyze the performance of for a specific use namely the analysis of frames in from an empirical point of with the objective of shedding light on a potential use of generative models in journalistic frame analysis is a concept from which consists of studying the way in which news stories are presented on an and what aspects are is a merely informative vision given in an or is it intended to leave a moral is a news article being presented from an economic point of or from a more emotional the examples above correspond to different frames with which an article can be the concept of news framing has been studied in computing as a step beyond topic modeling and sentiment and for this in recent pretrained language models have been used for finetuning the classification process of these frames but the emergence of generative models opens the possibility of doing promptengineering of these classification instead of the finetuning approach investigated so our work aims to address this research gap by posing the following research what are the main frames in the news headlines about the antivaccine as reported in newspapers across european icmr june greece david alonso del barrio and daniel can prompt engineering be used for classification of lines according
